Package net.sourceforge.plantuml.teavm.browser

Class PlantUMLBrowser

java.lang.Object
net.sourceforge.plantuml.teavm.browser.PlantUMLBrowser
public class PlantUMLBrowser extends Object
PlantUML rendering engine for browser environments, compiled to JavaScript via TeaVM.

Overview

This class provides a bridge between JavaScript code running in a browser and the PlantUML Java rendering engine. It exposes a global JavaScript function plantumlRender(lines, elementId) that web pages can call to render diagrams.

Architecture: JavaScript-driven paradigm

The design follows a "JS-driven" architecture where:
  • JavaScript handles: UI events, user input, debouncing, line splitting, DOM element selection, and overall application flow
  • Java handles: PlantUML parsing and SVG rendering only
This separation keeps the Java code minimal and allows maximum flexibility for web developers to integrate PlantUML however they want.

Why we need a worker thread

TeaVM compiles Java to JavaScript, but JavaScript is single-threaded and event-driven. To support Java's synchronous blocking APIs (like Thread.sleep() or Object.wait()), TeaVM uses a coroutine-based approach that transforms blocking calls into asynchronous JavaScript Promises.

The Viz.js constraint

PlantUML uses Viz.js (a JavaScript port of GraphViz) to render class diagrams, component diagrams, and other diagrams that require graph layout. Viz.js has an asynchronous API: 
 Viz.instance().then(viz => viz.renderString(dot, options))
Our GraphVizjsTeaVMEngine class uses TeaVM's @Async annotation to make this async call appear synchronous to Java code. However, this only works when called from a "TeaVM coroutine context" - essentially, from within a TeaVM thread.

What happens without the worker thread

If JavaScript calls our render function directly (e.g., from a setTimeout callback or an event listener), the call happens in a "native JS context", not a TeaVM coroutine context. When the code reaches the Viz.js async call, TeaVM throws: 
 Error: Suspension point reached from non-threading context
 (perhaps, from native JS method).
 See https://teavm.org/docs/runtime/coroutines.html

The solution: a dedicated worker thread

We solve this by:
  1. Starting a background thread at initialization (in main())
  2. Having the JS-callable function just queue a render request and wake the thread
  3. The worker thread performs the actual rendering in the correct coroutine context
This pattern ensures all PlantUML rendering (including Viz.js calls) happens in a context where TeaVM's async-to-sync transformation works correctly.

Usage from JavaScript

 // Initialize (call once when page loads)
 main();
 
 // Render a diagram
 const source = "@startuml\nAlice -> Bob : hello\n@enduml";
 const lines = source.split(/\r\n|\r|\n/);
 plantumlRender(lines, "output-div-id");

Thread safety

The class uses a simple producer-consumer pattern:
  • Producer: requestRender() called from JS, sets pending request and notifies
  • Consumer: workerLoop() waits for requests, processes them one at a time
If multiple render requests arrive while one is being processed, only the latest request is kept (the previous pending request is overwritten). This is intentional: when a user is typing, we only care about rendering the latest version.
